"At this point it's not even worth talking about"
(May contain spoilers for previous seasons)
It started in summer 2014 with the first adaptation of Tokyo Ghoul Manga airing. The anime remained faithful to the manga and the story itself was interesting combined with some gore and it attracted a large audience and ratings were good too. Both manga readers and anime only watchers were happy.
Then came the √A. Now in the first season they had 12 episode and serialized about 50 chapters of manga that is good. But in second season they still went with 12 episode series but decided to finish it there. Now theoptions were either to compress 94 chapters in 12 episodes or change the story and omit some details and they went with the later which left the manga readers furious.


Fast forward 3 years, in spring 2018 came the adaptation of tokyo ghoul:re , now the RE manga itself was a bit tricky because fight scenes were not very well drawn and for some reason the author decided to revive every dead character. Now the anime adaptation decided to completely forget about the √A and assume that everyone has read the manga which was definitely not the case and this time it left every anime only watcher confused and scratching their head because they don't know most of the things that happened in the second half of the Tokyo Ghoul which Studio Pierrot decided to throw in dump.


And finally 4 years later after the starting of Tokyo Ghoul we've reached the bottom of the pit after descending every level for 4 seasons. That's right I'm talking about the Tokyo Ghoul:re season 2. Now with this one they had the same situation as in √A either follow the manga by compressing it or write it on your own like they did in √A. But they thought hey we've already done the later now lets try the former and not much to say they failed miserably. This time they somehow managed to make both manga readers and anime only watchers angry, confused and disappointed. Anime only watchers didn't even know what was going on half the season and manga readers were very disappointed with the terrible pacing.


Story: 4/10


(Just read the manga if you're curious about the story)


The story does follow the manga but at the same time it doesn't with almost every detail getting omitted which leaves characters as hollow as 1 dimensional objects with no development at all.


Characters: 1/10

There is no character development. WIth almost every character getting revived we have about 3 times more characters than episodes which leaves no development to anyone at all.


Sound: 5/10

Only the OP by TK was good, rest of the osts were of the same quality as the anime.


Animation: 6/10

The animations were pretty ok compared to the previous season.


Overall: It's like a disappointment which everyone predicted and it came out to be just that way.

I watched this and stuck through it mainly just to see how it handled a few things from the manga.
The manga had some issues near the end where you might be able to say it was hard to follow, paced bizarrely, and some characters' actions may not make a lot of sense.
These 12 episodes exacerbate all of those issues. If you're somebody who didn't or does not want to read the manga I could not understand how you would understand or derive any enjoyment out of the plot of these twelve episode which represent around 60-70 chapters of the manga. 
The opening and ending themesare the best things it has going for it. \n
The animation and art overall are better than expected but that isn't saying a whole lot. \n
All around it's a pretty poor adaptation of the culmination of a series which had its fair share of flaws. I think anyone who hasn't read the manga would be hard pressed to make sense of all of the characters and what is going on. This speaks volumes because the overall plot is not all that complicated. \n
However more importantly I don't see how anyone who hasn't read the manga would suffer through watching it. \n
I would like to say that this isn't the typical elitist read the manga because it's better post. The adaptation was just really poorly handled all around for Tokyo Ghoul, and these last 12 episodes in particularly so.

As a non manga reader, this was a total disaster. 
I graded it 6 out of nostalgia and because the last 3 episodes somewhat followed some continuity and had more of the original characters. 
I've spent weeks persevering and watching, not wanting to believe this is what the series really amounted to... just randomness with stories and characters without truly allowing the audience to form a bond with these characters... yet, week after week these characters were given lots of screen time but then at some point, they die with a long monologue that's supposed to be touching, but we feel nothing because, "who thehell were these people anyway?"


As I watched, it seemed to me that the person in charge was more concerned about aesthetics and cool fighting scenes and sound effects and background music... but even all that is lost, because that linear... or rather, that cohesiveness to the story is missing. 


The only saving grace... the only thing I really appreciated from this story is Hide... again, because I'm a non manga reader. 


Anyway, as someone who hates dropping anime, I'm glad this is all over so I can move on.

The epic conclusion to a beloved story. Told across 2 manga series, with a total of 4 anime seasons. It has one of the largest casts, each with their own motivations and roles to play throughout the story, and each of them has their own character development arcs. It is a grand story, one that gives you the sense that there is so much going on in the background, that will all somehow interconnect with each other in the end. The romance is desirable, and the action sequences are next level. Overall, it is one of the greater series out there, which I think everyoneshould atleast give it a try.


The story I just described however, is not Tokyo Ghould:re's anime adaptation.


This anime, is the most disappointing anime of 2018. I beg you to refrain from watching this, and instead read the manga, or else your opinion of the series as a whole may be forever destroyed.


I truly pity the anime-only's, because you guys are probably so confused with what's going on, or will be. Because, they don't explain anything. I'm honestly not surprised, since they took over 100 chapters of the manga, and squeezed it into 12 episodes. Some of the new characters you don't even get to know! They just have their names called out to by other characters, and that's the only way you can identify them. Like, who the hell thought that it was a good idea to do this?!


In short, the story is so convoluted and awkwardly told that you end up not even caring anymore about what's happening.


The art is low tier, and the animation is clunky. It just looks bad, because of how they animated it using such a small budget, I would assume.


The sound is the only redeeming quality of the show. The OP and ED are pretty nice, even if they can't compare to the first season of Tokyo Ghoul. The V.A.'s weren't bad, but some of the sound effects sounded a little off. Not enough to bother you honestly.


As I previously stated, the characters are all just thrown down the dump. Anime-only's will never get to know them, or even care about any of them. Plus, this might be nitpicking but, they completely messed up Touka's hair color. She intentionally dyed it a light blue, which you can see from the manga cover, yet they didn't change that here in the anime. Atleast get the character design right, if you're just going to completely ignore everything else! Furuta's character however, was done rather well. I enjoyed his antics, even if they were messed up.


I'm still mad about not getting to see Hsiao animated, or even introduced properly. Atleast the gigantic oppai's would have slightly redeemed the show.... xD


The action scenes were the worst. You can't even tell what's going on most of the time, not that you'd care about it by the time you got there. Now, I'm not saying every episode is bad. There were some good ones, but the majority far outweighs the minority.


I did enjoy seeing the conclusion of Kaneki's struggles, but I just wished that the journey leading up to that could have been done better. Give it better animation and more time. Get the character design's right, and stop jumping from place to place in the story as if you're doing a flashback sequence for the entire season. Then maybe, just maybe, Tokyo Ghoul:re would have been a good anime adaptation.


Thank you for reading this review! I hope you have a wonderful day, wherever you are!

Tokyo Ghoul got way too complicated. I haven't read the manga, but from what I've heard, this anime is a disgraceful adaption. I would assume that the manga was actually able to introduce characters and pace the story well where the anime could not, and that is why this season was an awful way to end the series. Though, it may not be the end, which is even worse. 
So, like I said, this season was overly complicated. It kept me from caring about anything too much. This carries over from last season, but this was handled so poorly as far as the characters go.The anime essentially gives you a bunch of characters, tells you you have to care about them, and then doesn't tell you WHY you have to care about them. It doesn't even SHOW why you have to care about them. So, basically, I spent this season watching fights and developments and epiphanies and conclusions happen for every character under the sun when the series should've stuck with what gave it its charm in the first place: Kaneki. 


The story was done awfully as well. I couldn't really follow it because it jumped around way too much. Even if there wasn't a big time skip, there was a lot of character development that was just glossed over. The anime would give you point A and point Z without anything in between. I'd get hooked on part of the story developing, and then it would just fizzle out or reveal its conclusion right away. There was no suspense or excitement when I was watching this. The one thing I was waiting for finally happened in this season, which is why I didn't rate it lower, but they still kind of botched the whole thing because it was way too rushed. 


Somehow the season managed to have touching end despite me not giving a damn about most of the characters, but overall this season was a big disappointment. It kind of feels like you can't watch it unless you already know what's going on beforehand, but even the people that do know what's going on and have read the manga don't like the anime, so Tokyo Ghoul is kind of just a flop. No offense. 


Everything else was pretty average. The art was fine, the sound was fine, I didn't have to force myself to sit through the episodes, but I didn't have a good time watching it. I will say that the story slowed down and became enjoyable toward the end, but that's about the only good thing I can say about the anime overall. My advice: give up on the Tokyo Ghoul anime.

(FYI, miniature spoilers ahead)
It had so much potential, especially with such a fantastic Opening, yet after a certain time I just couldn't understand what was happening anymore.
Story (1/10):
There is none. It was kind of understandable what was happening in the beginning, but after seeing Episode 8, I gave up trying to understand the situations that were appearing in front of my eyes. They're seemingly attempting to cram as much of the Manga in as they can without any regard to the viewer's knowledge.
Art (7/10):
If you have seen Tokyo Ghoul:re, you'll be pleased (or not) to know that the Art style and Animation is identical. Thevisuals are nicely made. As always, the Opening is breathtaking, as with every other Tokyo Ghoul Opening.\n\n
Sound (10/10):\n
The sound quality is good with no audibly displeasing parts as of writing this (8 Episodes out of 12). Opening is katharsis by TK, which is honestly fantastic.\n\n
Character Development (2/10):\n
There was character development, don't get me wrong... but it was just way too god damn fast. It's as if you'd see a potato and the next second it's mutating into a massive killing machine that has absolutely no control of itself anymore, gets killed a minute later, and then turns out to be still alive, but never appears again because it's time for the carrot to do its quick entry.... Did you understand that? No? Me neither. Welcome to Tokyo Ghoul:re 2nd Season.\n\n
Enjoyment (3/10):\n
It would've been a easy 7/10 if they'd stick more or less to the same speed as the beginning episodes. It would've been even higher if they'd have built it like Tokyo Ghoul:re and maybe given us a 3rd Season.\n\n
Overall (2/10):\n
As mentioned above, it had the potential to be so much better, but after a while it became so chaotic I had to give up and just watch it without asking the story behind it. Needless to say, I feel betrayed and disappointed.\n\n
As of writing this, I still have 4 episodes to go that I will watch, but it's most likely going to be playing on a secondary monitor, with me focusing on something more important.

This will be my first review.  I will try my best to my point across and avoid any spoilers the I can.  As a fan of the Tokyo Ghoul franchise I feel the need to write a review for this anime.  
I grew up in the Toonami generation, watching shows like Dragon Ball Z, Yuu Yuu Hakusho, Sailor Moon, Rurouni Kenshin, Gundam, and other shounen action anime.  However, it was only until about 4 years ago, when the rebooted Toonami aired and they started showing Crunchyroll ads during commercial breaks, that I was introduced to a whole bunch of other animethat I wasn't unaware of at the time.  


It was around this time that I stumbled upon an anime call "Tokyo Ghoul" and I fell in love with it, so much so that I also bought the first 7 volumes of the manga.  While I love Tokyo Ghoul I will admit it has it's flaws, (mostly the fact that the anime cut out some scenes from the manga).  However I still liked the first season.


Fast forward 4 years after the first season and we now have "Tokyo Ghoul:re 2nd Season" and while I wouldn't say it's unbearable to watch, its hard to stay engaged with this anime seeing how poorly Studio Pierrot is handling it.


Story: 3

This is the main problem with the show.  I haven't read the manga for :Re yet so I don't really know what is happening at this point.  However, you do not have to have read the manga or have watched a lot of anime in general to tell you that this show was rushed.  Everything in this show is going by too fast, jumping from one scene to another.  Because of this it is hard to get a grasp of what is going on.  There is not enough time to get to know the characters or to get a grasps of the situation at the moment.


Art/Animation: 6

Compared to the original TG the art seems prettier.  However when it comes to animation its a bit lacking compared to the original.  It has it's moments though. 


Sound: 6

The best thing I can say about the second season of :Re is that they brought back TK from Ling Toshite Shigure to do the op.  "THE OP Katharsis IS FIRE", it rivals "Unravel".  Other than that sound is alright, however they use various sound bits that came from online somewhere that you might have heard before.


Characters: 6

I don't really have much to say about the characters.  Kaneki does seems a bit cooler than he was in the first season of :Re.


Enjoyment: 5.5

The story is not being handled well.  However its still "Tokyo Ghoul" and concept is there, which is fine by me.  So there is still some enjoyment to be had with this show.


Overall: 5

Tokyo Ghoul :re 2nd season could have been great, however that is not case.  Maybe its because Studio Pierrot is also working on Black Clover and Boruto, so the team working on TG :re might not have had much in terms of resources and had to make do with what they had.  If that's the case I'm willing to give them the benefit of the doubt.  I'm not say don't watch this anime, but if you decide to watch it, don't expect too much or you will be disappointed.

*This my first review*
In this review I will mention previous seasons of a Tokyo ghoul, so some spoilers may be mentioned. 
Seeing as Tokyo ghoul was the first anime I watched completely and manga series I read as it was being published, it has a special place in my heart. Nonetheless that does not excuse the fact that this series did get worse each season, and has large plot holes for anime only watchers. 
In my opinion I thought the first season of Tokyo ghoul was was enjoyable , followed the manga well (only missing a few points) and was something I would recommend watching.The animation was fine and captured fight sequences to a good enough standard, plus you can’t forget the rightfully popular OP ‘Unravel’ 


Tokyo Ghoul √A

Then the second season rolled around... wow. With all the aspects of the first season and some awesome OST’s. it looked promising at first glance, but it didn’t follow the source material (for the most part) and is basically not cannon.


Tokyo Ghoul:re 

After a long wait, Tokyo ghoul:re aired. Due to the fact  Tokyo Ghoul √A didn’t follow the events of the manga anime only watchers were left confused. I thought it would be okay though, and regain the great timing, animation and story aspect of the first season that Root A missed out on. I sure was wrong... in my opinion the entire 2 seasons of Tokyo ghoul:re felt rushed, covering way to many chapters in the first episode alone (only getting progressively worse as it continued) I didn’t like the art style in TG:re and the animation was poor. Resulting in the fight sequences feeling somewhat static. The only redeeming feature of Tokyo ghoul:re for me was the soundtrack, with some of the tracks from previous seasons it made me feel nostalgic.


In conclusion I would say just skip watching Tokyo ghoul:re and read the manga instead. I like Tokyo ghoul as a whole, but just wanted TG:re to end so I could watch something else. Obviously this is just my personal opinion, and it’s good if you enjoyed Tokyo Ghoul:re even though I didn’t.

Probably the most disappointing modern adaptation to date, both Anime only watchers and Manga hardcore fans that claim the source material to be a masterpiece, all have turned their back on the abomination that one body could take for granted, “Tokyo Ghoul:re”, with the prequel being just as controversially bad, this sequel of the same name told us to hold its beer, and that wasn't even half of the story.
I'm an Anime-only watcher, I never read a single chapter of the Manga, and never was exposed to any of the “spoilers” you see being spammed on the internet.
Nevertheless, and given both recent adaptations, they remainone of the worse comebacks ever, at least in my experience.


Story (3/10):

Just like the prequel, and even more, the pacing was ridiculously fast, even my Manga reader sibling commented on how fast and confusing it was, let alone for Anime-only watcher normie me that had no idea on the chronological order of anything that happened in the season, literally, they go from one period of time worth of content to another with no alert, and it isn't a bad thing to do per se (Baccano! is a great example on how to accomplish that the right way), they themselves made it not work somehow.

The progression as well as poor and bad-received from my part, I was basically starting at the screen trying to figure out what was the meaning of what's happening, it felt more like a chore than actual entertainment.

Aside from the bad direction, the story, in general, fell by a great margin in terms of quality, and I can see the potential there, a lot of turn around moments and twists didn't have such impact, and most were forced and out of nowhere, like you'sd have episodes houses up to five or six big reveals, and none of them gives the other a moment of breather to tone down the intensity, no, it was more like a global traffic accident. Like, what is a Kagune anymore?


Art (7/10):

Probably the only decent aspect that “Tokyo Ghoul:re 2” has going on other than the vocals.

And even that wasn't for the most part, there are the big moments of shine that have a noticeable rise in quality, but almost the majority of animation was just a lazy bad move from their part, most talking about the distorted anatomy and the slow movements on scenes that were supposed to feel faster.

I do give them one thing though, and that is the backgrounds, so realistic and do standout on their own and yet make a great job blending in the other not-too-realistic characters, and it works flawlessly.


Sound (8/10):

See that eight? That's talking mostly about the opening theme song alone, Katharsis gave me a new aura to associate Tokyo Ghoul with. As much of an iconic Unravel was, I just can't help but give Katharsis the crown that Unravel held for so long, it just works perfectly, especially for a story with the same atmosphere as Tokyo Ghoul.

The voice acting, on the other hand, wasn't my proudest experience here, a lot of screaming was involved, and you know how bad that can get.

Too bad they did not bring back some of the old soundtracks along, like the fantastic “Glassy Sky”. Just why did they think changing to something new would work better?


Characters (2/10):

A true shame, I do believe that Tokyo Ghoul had some of the greatest characters, that is until the “:re” adaptation joined the chat. There is particularly no sense in dealing with something called “character development” in this shitfest of colliding misfits.

If anything, that was an intentional downgrade, the interesting Kaneki for instance, goes from his raging emo depression to a normie nerdy looking guy, to then out of the blue breaking the emo records once again, and all of that in the same episode, bruh, catch a breather, will ya?

Again, they went with the biggest weakness of the prequel and introduced a ton of other characters that we never got any background about, more specifically, think about it like crowd characters with names that they keep shaving up in your face the entire episode.

There were a lot of interesting backstories with huge potential, but they just didn't live up to my expectations, with the return of some characters we long thought were dead, and the death of many others, sense loses its meaning and you end up not giving any L's.


Enjoyment (5/10):

Basically, when you're too into some Anime that you don't enjoy anymore, but still dedicate some time to watching it for the sake of completing it, and I'm a completionist as I like to call myself, if it sucks, I'll rant in the review.

I did, however, experience one of my new favorite songs, Katharsis, that's probably the only good thing I'll remember about this adaptation, it really does feel bad, how such a big renowned series like this, gets such a low-level conclusion, even after a long time of wait from us fans.


Overall (5/10):

So glad I went through this, and so sad at the same time for how bad it was. If you're already planning to watch this, chances are you made it through the first three seasons, and only this abomination is still standing between you and saying “I watched Tokyo Ghoul”.

It's adaptations like this that make you appreciate how great shows like “Attack on Titan” and “My Hero Academia” have it, I'm not trying to steer any controversy here, if you like your Tokyo Ghoul, then nobody is stopping you from seeing this season, again, I'm just stating my opinion, and it's far from being a fact.
